u (bus), ch/tch, ph, sh, th, wh, ng, l-blends, r-blends, s-blends, 3-letter blends.
Point to the spelling, say the letter names and sound or sounds, and have students repeat.
Use the articulation videos for any sound students need more support with. Have students write the spelling or spellings as they say the sound.
Did Fran stop to help you?
We slept in the big tent.
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: Animals Are All Around Us
Display the picture on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Welcome students to their phonics and word study resources and establish class goals.
Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Segmenting CVC Words
Ask students to repeat and blend the sounds into a word:
Ask students to repeat and segment the word into the sounds they hear:
Tap each sound as you say it.
Say the sounds below. Ask students to repeat and blend the sounds into a word.
Say each whole word below. Ask students to repeat and segment the word into the sounds they hear. Tell them to tap each sound as they say it. Provide corrective feedback.

Distribute the Student Book. Have students write their names on the cover and allow them time to browse the book. Explain that, at the end of the unit, they will take the book home to create a library of readings.
Review any class procedures and use of additional materials, as appropriate.

Although you have placed students into the materials based on the pre-assessments, these first units in Level 3 will provide additional opportunities to deepen your understanding of each students instructional needs.

. Have students add single consonants, blends, and digraphs to each pattern to see how many words they can make. Have them record their word lists.

Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Save That Stump.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write about whether they think Mom will get rid of the stump after a while and why.
Allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write before writing.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.
Students can complete the writing during independent work time.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Discuss that the illustration shows a stump. Explain that a stump is what is left in the ground when a tree is chopped down.
Have students find the stump in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.

for chipmunks. They can make their home there.

to you? Tell your partner about it.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what they do to the big elm tree. (chop)
How does a rotten stump benefit, or help, animals? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why is Mom impressed with Beth?
Where would you most likely see a rotten stump? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Read: Pill Bugs Are Our Cousins
Guide students through a reading of Pill Bugs Are Our Cousins.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a Fact
Have students write the most interesting fact they learned from the text.
Have them draw a picture to accompany their fact.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Discuss that a pill bug is a kind of animal called a crustacean. These animals have two antennae, or feelers, two eyes, lots of legs, and a hard shell but no bones. Have students find the pill bug in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.

because they are both in the cat family.
Ask: Who are some of your
? How are they related or connected to you? Tell your partner about it.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what pill bugs use to breathe. (gills)
Why do the shrimp say that pill bugs are their relatives or cousins? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why might pill bugs need to protect themselves?
Have you ever seen a pill bug or another crustacean? Where did you see it?

Discuss how to chunk the text into meaningful parts in order to read it. Point out the words in the first sentence that go together and can be chunked:

Explain that fluent readers read each chunk as a phrase, pausing briefly between the chunks. Model how to use chunking to read the first sentence aloud. Have students echo read the sentence replicating your phrasing.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say,
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Who Am I?
Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
Fran shops for chips. Chad likes fresh fish.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle has a tricky question asked with a series of hints and an answer.

For the first reading, have students read the question while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingsone asks the question, while the other answers it.

Prompt students to find all the words in the riddles with short vowel spellings and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

Ask them to find an important fact about sloths from each paragraph in the text and write the fact in a box.

Then have students use these facts to write a 1-2 sentence summary of the text. Have students share their summaries orally with a partner before writing them to make sure they are clearly stated and brief.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Poster and Summary

Have students create posters that show the moral of the story. They can draw a picture that shows details from the story along with speech balloons with the frogs dialogue. Suggest that they write a title that summarizes the moral, such as Look Before You Leap or Think Before You Act.
Then have them use the poster to summarize the story to a partner.
Finally, have them write their summaries.
